data.current_summary: Get a location for subsequent document upload PUT request
data.summary_suggestion: Initiate benefits document submission and obtain upload location
data.description_suggestion: Initiates a new benefits document submission and returns a unique submission identifier (GUID) and a pre-signed upload location URL. The returned location URL is valid for 15 minutes and must be used with a PUT request to upload the actual document payload. This is the first step in the document submission workflow. Returns HTTP 202 Accepted with submission details including the GUID for tracking and the location URL for the subsequent PUT request.
data.reasoning: Original summary is passive and unclear about the action. Description is completely missing. Added clarity about the two-step process, the 15-minute window, the GUID for tracking, and the HTTP 202 response. This helps AI agents understand this is an initialization step that must be followed by a PUT request.

Description has good technical details but lacks context about the two-step workflow, the 15-minute window, the purpose of the ETag, and the asynchronous validation process. Added clarity about when this endpoint is used in the workflow, the multipart structure requirements, the validation timing, and what success means. This helps AI agents understand the upload mechanics and expectations.

data.current_description:
Accepts document metadata, document binary, and attachment binaries. Full URL, including
query parameters, provided from POST `/document_uploads`.

## Example Payload

The following demonstrates a (redacted) multipart payload suitable for submitting to the PUT
endpoint. Most programming languages should have provisions for assembling a multipart
payload like this without having to do so manually.

```
--17de1ed8f01442b2a2d7a93506314b76
Content-Disposition: form-data; name="metadata"
Content-Type: application/json

{"veteranFirstName": "Jane",
"veteranLastName": "Doe",
"fileNumber": "012345678",
"zipCode": "97202",
"source": "MyVSO",
"docType": "21-22"
"businessLine": "CMP"}
--17de1ed8f01442b2a2d7a93506314b76
Content-Disposition: form-data; name="content"
Content-Type: application/pdf

<Binary PDF contents>
--17de1ed8f01442b2a2d7a93506314b76
Content-Disposition: form-data; name="attachment1"
Content-Type: application/pdf

<Binary PDF attachment contents>
--17de1ed8f01442b2a2d7a93506314b76--
```

This PUT request would have an overall HTTP Content-Type header:

```
Content-Type: multipart/form-data; boundary=17de1ed8f01442b2a2d7a93506314b76
```

Note that the Content-Disposition parameter "name" in each part must be the expected values
"metadata" , "content", "attachment1"..."attachmentN". The attachment attributes must be named 
exactly as they are listed here (case sensitive), for example: "attachment_1" or "Attachment2"
are invalid.

This is an example curl command:

```
curl -v -L -X PUT '<Location from \uploads>' -F 'metadata="{\"veteranFirstName\": \"Jane\",\"veteranLastName\": \"Doe\",\"fileNumber\": \"012345678\",\"zipCode\": \"97202\",\"source\": \"MyVSO\",\"docType\": \"21-22\",\"businessLine\": \"CMP\"}"';type=application/json' -F 'content=@"content.pdf"' -F 'attachment1=@"file1.pdf"' -F 'attachment2=@"another_file.pdf"'
```
data.summary_suggestion: Upload benefits document submission with metadata and attachments
data.description_suggestion: Uploads a complete benefits document submission to the pre-signed location URL obtained from the POST /uploads endpoint. The request must use multipart/form-data format containing: (1) metadata as JSON with Veteran information and claim details, (2) content as the primary PDF document, and (3) optional attachment PDFs (attachment1, attachment2, etc.). The URL is valid for 15 minutes from POST request. Returns HTTP 200 with an ETag header containing an MD5 hash for data integrity verification. Note: Successful upload does not guarantee successful processing; documents are validated asynchronously and may fail validation after upload. No authorization header required for this request.
data.reasoning: Original summary is too passive and vague. Description has good technical details but lacks context about the two-step workflow, the 15-minute window, the purpose of the ETag, and the asynchronous validation process. Added clarity about when this endpoint is used in the workflow, the multipart structure requirements, the validation timing, and what success means. This helps AI agents understand the upload mechanics and expectations.

message: Operation 'getBenefitsDocumentUploadStatus' has semantic quality issues: vague_summary, missing_output_details, missing_context. Original summary is generic. Description mentions updating /uploads/report but doesn't explain what statuses are possible or what the response contains. Added comprehensive list of possible statuses, explanation of key fields like final_status and Date of Receipt, and guidance on when to use this endpoint versus the bulk report endpoint. This helps AI agents understand what information they'll receive and how to interpret it.

data.current_summary: Get status for a previous benefits document upload
data.current_description:
A request to the `/uploads/{id}` endpoint will return a real-time status for that GUID, and update its status in `/uploads/report`.

The `updated_at` field indicates the last time the status for a given GUID was updated.
data.summary_suggestion: Retrieve real-time submission status for a benefits document upload
data.description_suggestion: Retrieves the current processing status of a previously submitted benefits document using the submission GUID. Returns real-time status (not cached) including: status value (Pending, Uploaded, Received, Processing, Success, VBMS, Error, or Expired), VA Date of Receipt (when status reaches Received), error code and detail if applicable, final_status flag indicating if submission will no longer update, and updated_at timestamp. Use this endpoint for individual submission tracking; use POST /uploads/report for bulk status checks of multiple submissions.
data.reasoning: Original summary is generic. Description mentions updating /uploads/report but doesn't explain what statuses are possible or what the response contains. Added comprehensive list of possible statuses, explanation of key fields like final_status and Date of Receipt, and guidance on when to use this endpoint versus the bulk report endpoint. This helps AI agents understand what information they'll receive and how to interpret it.

message: Operation 'getBenefitsDocumentUploadStatusReport' has semantic quality issues: vague_summary, missing_input_details, missing_output_details. Original summary doesn't mention the input requirement (list of GUIDs). Description mentions caching but doesn't explain what the request payload should contain or what the response structure is. Added clarity about the input format (array of GUIDs), the response structure for each submission, the one-hour cache limitation, and guidance on when to use this endpoint versus the single-submission endpoint. This helps AI agents understand how to construct the request and interpret the response.

data.current_summary: Get a bulk status report for a list of previous uploads
data.current_description:
Due to current system limitations, data for the `/uploads/report` endpoint is cached for one hour.

A request to the `/uploads/{id}` endpoint will return a real-time status for that GUID, and update its status in `/uploads/report`.

The `updated_at` field indicates the last time the status for a given GUID was updated.
data.summary_suggestion: Retrieve cached status report for multiple benefits document submissions
data.description_suggestion: Retrieves the processing status for multiple benefits document submissions in a single request. Accepts a JSON payload containing an array of submission GUIDs (ids). Returns status information for each GUID including: status value, error code and detail if applicable, final_status flag, and updated_at timestamp. Data is cached for one hour, so status updates may be delayed up to 60 minutes. For real-time status of individual submissions, use GET /uploads/{id} instead. Useful for monitoring multiple concurrent submissions efficiently.
data.reasoning: Original summary doesn't mention the input requirement (list of GUIDs). Description mentions caching but doesn't explain what the request payload should contain or what the response structure is. Added clarity about the input format (array of GUIDs), the response structure for each submission, the one-hour cache limitation, and guidance on when to use this endpoint versus the single-submission endpoint. This helps AI agents understand how to construct the request and interpret the response.

message: Operation 'postBenefitsDocumentUploadValidateDocument' has semantic quality issues: missing_context, missing_output_details. Summary is good and clear. Description has comprehensive technical details but lacks clarity about the response format for errors (what does 422 response contain?) and could better emphasize this is an optional pre-validation step in the workflow. Added explicit mention of response codes and their meanings, clarified that this is a pre-validation step before the full submission, and improved the workflow context by referencing the PUT endpoint. This helps AI agents understand when to use this endpoint and how to handle responses.

data.current_summary: Validate an individual document against system file requirements
data.current_description:
Using this endpoint will decrease the likelihood of errors associated with individual documents during
the submission process. Validations performed:
 * Document is a valid PDF (Note: `Content-Type` header value must be "application/pdf")
* Document does not have a user password (an owner password is acceptable)
 * File size does not exceed 100 MB
* Page size does not exceed 78" x 101"

Each PDF document is sent as a direct file upload. The request body should contain nothing other than the document in
binary format. Binary multipart/form-data encoding is not supported. This endpoint does NOT validate metadata in JSON
 format.

This endpoint does NOT initiate the claims intake process or submit data to that process. After using this endpoint,
individual PDF documents can be combined and submitted as a payload using PUT `/path`.

A `200` response confirms that the individual document provided passes the system requirements.
 
A `422` response indicates one or more problems with the document that should be resolved before submitting it in the
full document submission payload.
data.description_suggestion: Validates an individual PDF document against VA Benefits Intake system requirements before submission. Performs the following checks: (1) Document is a valid PDF with Content-Type header set to "application/pdf", (2) Document does not have user-level password protection (owner passwords are acceptable), (3) File size does not exceed 100 MB, (4) Page dimensions do not exceed 78" x 101". Request body must contain only the binary PDF file; multipart/form-data encoding is not supported. This endpoint does NOT validate metadata or initiate claims processing. Returns HTTP 200 if all validations pass, or HTTP 422 with error details if validation fails. Use this endpoint to pre-validate documents before combining them into a full submission payload for the PUT /uploads/{location} endpoint.
data.reasoning: Summary is good and clear. Description has comprehensive technical details but lacks clarity about the response format for errors (what does 422 response contain?) and could better emphasize this is an optional pre-validation step in the workflow. Added explicit mention of response codes and their meanings, clarified that this is a pre-validation step before the full submission, and improved the workflow context by referencing the PUT endpoint. This helps AI agents understand when to use this endpoint and how to handle responses.

data.current_summary: Get a location for subsequent document upload PUT request
data.summary_suggestion: Initiate benefits document submission and obtain upload location
data.description_suggestion: Initiates a new benefits document submission and returns a unique submission identifier (GUID) and a pre-signed upload location URL. The returned location URL is valid for 15 minutes and must be used with a PUT request to upload the actual document payload. This is the first step in the document submission workflow. Returns HTTP 202 Accepted with submission details including the GUID for tracking and the location URL for the subsequent PUT request.
data.reasoning: Original summary is passive and unclear about the action. Description is completely missing. Added clarity about the two-step process, the 15-minute window, the GUID for tracking, and the HTTP 202 response. This helps AI agents understand this is an initialization step that must be followed by a PUT request.

data.current_description:
Accepts document metadata, document binary, and attachment binaries. Full URL, including
query parameters, provided from POST `/document_uploads`.

## Example Payload

The following demonstrates a (redacted) multipart payload suitable for submitting to the PUT
endpoint. Most programming languages should have provisions for assembling a multipart
payload like this without having to do so manually.

```
--17de1ed8f01442b2a2d7a93506314b76
Content-Disposition: form-data; name="metadata"
Content-Type: application/json

{"veteranFirstName": "Jane",
"veteranLastName": "Doe",
"fileNumber": "012345678",
"zipCode": "97202",
"source": "MyVSO",
"docType": "21-22"
"businessLine": "CMP"}
--17de1ed8f01442b2a2d7a93506314b76
Content-Disposition: form-data; name="content"
Content-Type: application/pdf

<Binary PDF contents>
--17de1ed8f01442b2a2d7a93506314b76
Content-Disposition: form-data; name="attachment1"
Content-Type: application/pdf

<Binary PDF attachment contents>
--17de1ed8f01442b2a2d7a93506314b76--
```

This PUT request would have an overall HTTP Content-Type header:

```
Content-Type: multipart/form-data; boundary=17de1ed8f01442b2a2d7a93506314b76
```

Note that the Content-Disposition parameter "name" in each part must be the expected values
"metadata" , "content", "attachment1"..."attachmentN". The attachment attributes must be named 
exactly as they are listed here (case sensitive), for example: "attachment_1" or "Attachment2"
are invalid.

This is an example curl command:

```
curl -v -L -X PUT '<Location from \uploads>' -F 'metadata="{\"veteranFirstName\": \"Jane\",\"veteranLastName\": \"Doe\",\"fileNumber\": \"012345678\",\"zipCode\": \"97202\",\"source\": \"MyVSO\",\"docType\": \"21-22\",\"businessLine\": \"CMP\"}"';type=application/json' -F 'content=@"content.pdf"' -F 'attachment1=@"file1.pdf"' -F 'attachment2=@"another_file.pdf"'
```
data.summary_suggestion: Upload benefits document submission with metadata and attachments
data.description_suggestion: Uploads a complete benefits document submission to the pre-signed location URL obtained from the POST /uploads endpoint. The request must use multipart/form-data format containing: (1) metadata as JSON with Veteran information and claim details, (2) content as the primary PDF document, and (3) optional attachments (attachment1, attachment2, etc.). All PDF files must meet system requirements (valid PDF, no user password, 100 MB, page size 78"x101"). The request must be completed within 15 minutes of obtaining the upload location. Returns HTTP 200 with an ETag header containing an MD5 hash for data integrity verification. Successful upload transitions the submission status from Pending to Uploaded and initiates downstream validation and processing.
data.reasoning: Original summary is too passive and vague. Description contains useful technical details but lacks context about the workflow, timing constraints, and side effects. Added clarity about the 15-minute window, the multipart structure requirements, file constraints, the ETag response, and the status transition. This helps AI agents understand the critical timing requirement and what happens after upload.

data.current_summary: Get status for a previous benefits document upload
data.current_description:
A request to the `/uploads/{id}` endpoint will return a real-time status for that GUID, and update its status in `/uploads/report`.

The `updated_at` field indicates the last time the status for a given GUID was updated.
data.description_suggestion: Retrieves the real-time status of a previously submitted benefits document submission using its unique submission identifier (GUID). Returns the current submission status (Pending, Uploaded, Received, Processing, Success, VBMS, Error, or Expired), the VA Date of Receipt (when status reaches Received or beyond), and the last update timestamp. If the submission is in Error status, includes an error code and detailed explanation. The final_status field indicates whether the submission status will no longer change. This endpoint provides non-cached data and is recommended for individual submission tracking. For tracking multiple submissions, use POST /uploads/report instead.

data.summary_suggestion: Download submitted document package for debugging purposes
data.description_suggestion: Downloads a zip archive containing the decomposed components of a previously submitted benefits document package for debugging and verification purposes. The archive includes the parsed metadata (JSON) and all submitted PDF documents (primary content and attachments) as they were received and processed by the server. This endpoint is exclusively available in sandbox/testing environments and is not available in production. Downloaded files are automatically deleted after 10 days. Use this endpoint to verify that documents and metadata were correctly received and parsed by the system.

data.current_summary: Get a bulk status report for a list of previous uploads
data.current_description:
Due to current system limitations, data for the `/uploads/report` endpoint is cached for one hour.

A request to the `/uploads/{id}` endpoint will return a real-time status for that GUID, and update its status in `/uploads/report`.

The `updated_at` field indicates the last time the status for a given GUID was updated.
data.description_suggestion: Retrieves the status of multiple benefits document submissions in a single request by providing a list of submission identifiers (GUIDs). Returns an array of submission status records, each containing the current status (Pending, Uploaded, Received, Processing, Success, VBMS, Error, or Expired), VA Date of Receipt, error details if applicable, final_status indicator, and last update timestamp. Data is cached for one hour due to system limitations; for real-time status of individual submissions, use GET /uploads/{id} instead. This endpoint is recommended when tracking multiple submissions to reduce API calls.

data.current_summary: Validate an individual document against system file requirements
data.current_description:
Using this endpoint will decrease the likelihood of errors associated with individual documents during
the submission process. Validations performed:
 * Document is a valid PDF (Note: `Content-Type` header value must be "application/pdf")
* Document does not have a user password (an owner password is acceptable)
 * File size does not exceed 100 MB
* Page size does not exceed 78" x 101"

Each PDF document is sent as a direct file upload. The request body should contain nothing other than the document in
binary format. Binary multipart/form-data encoding is not supported. This endpoint does NOT validate metadata in JSON
 format.

This endpoint does NOT initiate the claims intake process or submit data to that process. After using this endpoint,
individual PDF documents can be combined and submitted as a payload using PUT `/path`.

A `200` response confirms that the individual document provided passes the system requirements.
 
A `422` response indicates one or more problems with the document that should be resolved before submitting it in the
full document submission payload.
data.description_suggestion: Validates an individual PDF document against VA Benefits Intake system requirements before submission. Performs the following validations: (1) Document is a valid PDF with Content-Type header set to "application/pdf", (2) Document does not have a user password (owner passwords are acceptable), (3) File size does not exceed 100 MB, (4) Page dimensions do not exceed 78" x 101". The request body must contain only the raw PDF binary; multipart/form-data encoding is not supported. This endpoint validates only the document file itself, not metadata. Returns HTTP 200 if all validations pass, or HTTP 422 with specific error details if validation fails. This is a pre-submission validation tool onlyit does not initiate claims processing or submit data downstream. Use this endpoint to identify and resolve document issues before combining documents into a full submission payload for the PUT /uploads/{path} endpoint.

data.current_description:
Accepts document metadata, document binary, and attachment binaries. Full URL, including
query parameters, provided from POST `/document_uploads`.

## Example Payload

The following demonstrates a (redacted) multipart payload suitable for submitting to the PUT
endpoint. Most programming languages should have provisions for assembling a multipart
payload like this without having to do so manually.

```
--17de1ed8f01442b2a2d7a93506314b76
Content-Disposition: form-data; name="metadata"
Content-Type: application/json

{"veteranFirstName": "Jane",
"veteranLastName": "Doe",
"fileNumber": "012345678",
"zipCode": "97202",
"source": "MyVSO",
"docType": "21-22"
"businessLine": "CMP"}
--17de1ed8f01442b2a2d7a93506314b76
Content-Disposition: form-data; name="content"
Content-Type: application/pdf

<Binary PDF contents>
--17de1ed8f01442b2a2d7a93506314b76
Content-Disposition: form-data; name="attachment1"
Content-Type: application/pdf

<Binary PDF attachment contents>
--17de1ed8f01442b2a2d7a93506314b76--
```

This PUT request would have an overall HTTP Content-Type header:

```
Content-Type: multipart/form-data; boundary=17de1ed8f01442b2a2d7a93506314b76
```

Note that the Content-Disposition parameter "name" in each part must be the expected values
"metadata" , "content", "attachment1"..."attachmentN". The attachment attributes must be named 
exactly as they are listed here (case sensitive), for example: "attachment_1" or "Attachment2"
are invalid.

This is an example curl command:

```
curl -v -L -X PUT '<Location from \uploads>' -F 'metadata="{\"veteranFirstName\": \"Jane\",\"veteranLastName\": \"Doe\",\"fileNumber\": \"012345678\",\"zipCode\": \"97202\",\"source\": \"MyVSO\",\"docType\": \"21-22\",\"businessLine\": \"CMP\"}"';type=application/json' -F 'content=@"content.pdf"' -F 'attachment1=@"file1.pdf"' -F 'attachment2=@"another_file.pdf"'
```
data.summary_suggestion: Upload benefits document submission with metadata and attachments
data.description_suggestion: Uploads a complete benefits document submission to the pre-signed location URL obtained from the POST /uploads endpoint. The request must use multipart/form-data format containing: (1) metadata as JSON with Veteran information and claim details, (2) content as the primary PDF document, and (3) optional attachments (attachment1, attachment2, etc.). All PDF files must meet system requirements (valid PDF, no user password, 100 MB, page size 78"x101"). The request must be completed within 15 minutes of obtaining the upload location. Returns HTTP 200 with an ETag header containing an MD5 hash for data integrity verification. Successful upload transitions the submission status from Pending to Uploaded and initiates downstream validation and processing.
data.reasoning: Original summary is too passive and vague. Description contains useful technical details but lacks context about the workflow, timing constraints, and side effects. Added clarity about the 15-minute window, the multipart structure requirements, file constraints, the ETag response, and the status transition. This helps AI agents understand the critical timing requirement and what happens after upload.

data.current_summary: Get status for a previous benefits document upload
data.current_description:
A request to the `/uploads/{id}` endpoint will return a real-time status for that GUID, and update its status in `/uploads/report`.

The `updated_at` field indicates the last time the status for a given GUID was updated.
data.description_suggestion: Retrieves the real-time status of a previously submitted benefits document submission using its unique submission identifier (GUID). Returns the current submission status (Pending, Uploaded, Received, Processing, Success, VBMS, Error, or Expired), the VA Date of Receipt (when status reaches Received or beyond), and the last update timestamp. If the submission is in Error status, includes an error code and detailed explanation. The final_status field indicates whether the submission status will no longer change. This endpoint provides non-cached data and is recommended for individual submission tracking. For tracking multiple submissions, use POST /uploads/report instead.

data.current_summary: Get a bulk status report for a list of previous uploads
data.current_description:
Due to current system limitations, data for the `/uploads/report` endpoint is cached for one hour.

A request to the `/uploads/{id}` endpoint will return a real-time status for that GUID, and update its status in `/uploads/report`.

The `updated_at` field indicates the last time the status for a given GUID was updated.
data.description_suggestion: Retrieves the status of multiple benefits document submissions in a single request by providing a list of submission identifiers (GUIDs). Returns an array of submission status records, each containing the current status (Pending, Uploaded, Received, Processing, Success, VBMS, Error, or Expired), VA Date of Receipt, error details if applicable, final_status indicator, and last update timestamp. Data is cached for one hour due to system limitations; for real-time status of individual submissions, use GET /uploads/{id} instead. This endpoint is recommended when tracking multiple submissions to reduce API calls.

Summary is good but description, while comprehensive, could be better organized for AI agent clarity. Restructured the description to clearly separate: validation criteria, request format requirements, scope limitations, response codes with meanings, and workflow context. data.current_summary: Validate an individual document against system file requirements
data.current_description:
Using this endpoint will decrease the likelihood of errors associated with individual documents during
the submission process. Validations performed:
 * Document is a valid PDF (Note: `Content-Type` header value must be "application/pdf")
* Document does not have a user password (an owner password is acceptable)
 * File size does not exceed 100 MB
* Page size does not exceed 78" x 101"

Each PDF document is sent as a direct file upload. The request body should contain nothing other than the document in
binary format. Binary multipart/form-data encoding is not supported. This endpoint does NOT validate metadata in JSON
 format.

This endpoint does NOT initiate the claims intake process or submit data to that process. After using this endpoint,
individual PDF documents can be combined and submitted as a payload using PUT `/path`.

A `200` response confirms that the individual document provided passes the system requirements.
 
A `422` response indicates one or more problems with the document that should be resolved before submitting it in the
full document submission payload.
data.description_suggestion: Validates an individual PDF document against VA Benefits Intake system requirements before submission. Performs the following validations: (1) Document is a valid PDF with Content-Type header set to "application/pdf", (2) Document does not have a user password (owner passwords are acceptable), (3) File size does not exceed 100 MB, (4) Page dimensions do not exceed 78" x 101". The request body must contain only the raw PDF binary; multipart/form-data encoding is not supported. This endpoint validates only the document file itself, not metadata. Returns HTTP 200 if all validations pass, or HTTP 422 with specific error details if validation fails. This is a pre-submission validation tool onlyit does not initiate claims processing or submit data downstream. Use this endpoint to identify and resolve document issues before combining documents into a full submission payload for the PUT /uploads/{path} endpoint.
